name: Butter Chicken
short: Creamy tomato curry with tender chicken
description: Succulent pieces of tandoori chicken simmered in a rich, creamy tomato-based gravy with aromatic spices and butter. A North Indian classic served with naan or rice.
history: Butter Chicken was invented in the 1950s by Kundan Lal Gujral at Moti Mahal restaurant in Delhi. It was created as a way to use leftover tandoori chicken by cooking it in a rich tomato-butter gravy.

name: Paneer Tikka Masala
short: Grilled cottage cheese in rich gravy
description: Char-grilled paneer cubes cooked in a creamy tomato-onion gravy with bell peppers, aromatic spices and fresh cream. A vegetarian delight.
history: Paneer Tikka Masala is a popular vegetarian adaptation of the famous Chicken Tikka Masala, originating from North Indian cuisine.

name: Chicken Biryani
short: Aromatic basmati rice with spiced chicken
description: Fragrant basmati rice layered with marinated chicken, caramelized onions, saffron, and aromatic spices. Slow-cooked to perfection and served with raita.
history: Biryani has Persian origins and was brought to India by Mughal rulers. It evolved into various regional styles, with Hyderabadi and Lucknowi biryani being the most famous.

name: Dal Makhani
description: Slow-cooked black lentils and kidney beans in a rich, creamy tomato-based gravy with butter and cream. A Punjabi delicacy that melts in your mouth.
history: Dal Makhani originated in Punjab and was popularized by Moti Mahal restaurant in Delhi. Traditionally, it's slow-cooked overnight for maximum flavor.

name: Paneer Tikka
description: Marinated cottage cheese cubes grilled to perfection with bell peppers and onions, served with mint chutney.
history: Paneer Tikka is a popular North Indian appetizer, originating from Punjab. It's the vegetarian version of the famous Chicken Tikka.

name: Samosa (2 pcs)
short: Crispy fried pastry with spiced potato filling
description: Golden-fried triangular pastries stuffed with spiced potatoes, peas, and aromatic herbs. Served hot with tamarind and mint chutney.
history: Samosas have Middle Eastern origins but became an integral part of Indian cuisine. They're now one of India's most beloved street foods.

name: Chole Bhature
short: Spicy chickpea curry with fluffy fried bread
description: Tangy and spicy chickpea curry served with large, fluffy deep-fried bread. A hearty North Indian breakfast favorite.
history: Chole Bhature originated in Punjab and is now a popular breakfast and street food across North India, especially in Delhi.

name: Vada Pav
description: Spicy mashed potato fritter sandwiched in a soft pav (bun) with chutneys and fried green chilies. Mumbai's iconic street food.
history: Vada Pav was invented in 1966 by Ashok Vaidya near Dadar station in Mumbai. It's now synonymous with Mumbai street food culture.

name: Masala Dosa
short: Crispy rice crepe with spiced potato filling
description: Thin, crispy fermented rice and lentil crepe filled with spiced potato masala. Served with sambar, coconut chutney, and tomato chutney.
history: Masala Dosa originated in Udupi, Karnataka in the early 20th century. It's now one of South India's most iconic dishes, enjoyed worldwide.

name: Idli Sambhar
short: Steamed rice cakes with lentil soup
description: Soft, fluffy steamed rice cakes served with aromatic lentil-vegetable soup, coconut chutney, and sambar powder.
history: Idli is an ancient South Indian dish mentioned in texts dating back to 920 CE. It's a staple breakfast in South India, known for being light and nutritious.

name: Gulab Jamun
short: Soft milk dumplings in rose-scented syrup
description: Soft, spongy milk-solid dumplings deep-fried and soaked in aromatic rose-cardamom sugar syrup. Served warm or cold.
history: Gulab Jamun has Persian origins and came to India during the Mughal era. The name comes from 'gulab' (rose water) and 'jamun' (a berry it resembles).

name: Rasgulla
short: Spongy cottage cheese balls in sugar syrup
description: Light, spongy cottage cheese balls cooked in light sugar syrup. A Bengali delicacy that's refreshingly sweet.
history: Rasgulla was created in Odisha but popularized by Bengali confectioner Nobin Chandra Das in the 19th century. There's still a friendly rivalry between Bengal and Odisha over its origin!

name: Kheer (Rice Pudding)
short: Creamy rice pudding with cardamom & nuts
description: Slow-cooked rice pudding made with milk, sugar, cardamom, and garnished with almonds, pistachios, and saffron strands.
history: Kheer is one of India's oldest desserts, mentioned in ancient texts. It's traditionally prepared during festivals and special occasions across India.

name: Jalebi
short: Crispy sweet spirals in sugar syrup
description: Crispy, deep-fried flour spirals soaked in saffron-infused sugar syrup. Best enjoyed hot and fresh.
history: Jalebi has Middle Eastern origins and came to India through ancient trade routes. It's now an integral part of Indian festivals and celebrations.

name: Masala Chai
short: Indian spiced tea with aromatic spices
description: Traditional Indian tea brewed with black tea leaves, milk, sugar, and aromatic spices like cardamom, ginger, and cloves.
history: Masala Chai became popular in India during the British colonial era but the practice of adding spices to tea has ancient Ayurvedic roots.

name: Mango Lassi
description: Thick, creamy smoothie made with fresh mangoes, yogurt, milk, and a touch of cardamom. Perfectly refreshing.
history: Lassi originates from Punjab and has been consumed for thousands of years. Mango lassi is a sweeter variation that became popular in the 1960s.

name: Nimbu Pani (Lemonade)
description: Freshly squeezed lemon juice with water, sugar, salt, and a hint of cumin. A perfect summer cooler.
history: Nimbu Pani is India's traditional thirst quencher, consumed for centuries. It's known for its perfect balance of sweet, salty, and tangy flavors.

name: Fresh Sugarcane Juice
description: Freshly pressed sugarcane juice with a squeeze of lime and ginger. Naturally sweet and incredibly refreshing.
history: Sugarcane juice has been consumed in India since ancient times. It's mentioned in Vedic texts and has been a popular street drink for centuries.
